text: If we want to give either an lightning talk or an experience talk about the same thing depending on how the reviewers feel about it should i submit two proposals or say in the notes that it could also be other thing and sumbit one thing.

text: How *does* scheduling work, anyway? Do you plan on really reserving e.g. 10 minutes slots for Lightning talks, then everybody is supposed to watch the videos simultaneously and ask questions afterwards? That would seem odd... So perhaps just slots for the questions, and people are asked to watch talks beforehand? Or how ...?

Questions were often already asked and answered during the talk through the chat, so there was more time for questions than just 2 minutes at the end

text: <@U012FH66MFW> There are 3 simultaneous tracks

elements.text: There are 3 simultaneous tracks

text: The one thing to note is that because everything is pre-recorded and pre-scheduled, there is no room for error. So if a talk is longer than the allocated time, it gets abruptly cut off when the slot is over.

elements.text: The one thing to note is that because everything is pre-recorded and pre-scheduled, there is no room for error. So if a talk is longer than the allocated time, it gets abruptly cut off when the slot is over.

text: What would have really helped last year is if the pre-recorded talks and posters had been made available 24 hours ahead of time, so that viewers could manage  clashes their own way, and prepare questions ahead of time.  As it was last year felt a bit rushed.  For an in-person conference you can mull over the speaker's talk, compose your question properly, and then find them at the coffee break, and last year's conference felt too choppy for that - I did no mulling because the next talk was starting _immediately_

text: We did this (make video available a few days before) for another conference-- in fact everybody there was expected to prewatch the talks, and it resulted in awesome QA rounds. Best questions/discussions I ever experienced

text: Finding people on discord can work for specific questions but it's something very different from a Q&A discussion after a talk, IMHO. Then again that was for a research conference, maybe that works out differently
